Problem:
Consider a system where the temperature distribution \\( u(x,t) \\) in a rod is described by the heat equation \\( u_t = ku_{xx} \\), where \\( k \\) is the thermal diffusivity constant. We examine the influence of an external heat source \\( q(x,t) \\) modeled by the transformation \\( f(u) = u + q(x,t) \\).

If at a certain time \\( t_1 \\), an intervention using a new external cooling function \\( g(u) = u - r(x,t) \\) (where \\( r(x,t) \\) is a cooling function) is applied, will the final state \\( u(x,T) \\) for T > t_1 depend only on the thermal diffusivity \\( k \\) and not on the initial heat source \\( q(x,t) \\) or cooling function \\( r(x,t) \\)?
Explanation: Both the initial heat source \\( q(x,t) \\) and the cooling intervention \\( r(x,t) \\) alter the temperature profiles at their respective times of application, affecting the evolution process and the final state at \\( T \\). They play crucial roles in determining the temperature distribution alongside the inherent properties of the heat diffusion characterized by \\( k \\).
